economic_context.details: Appoline's economic desperation was central to her confession narrative. She testified that when her husband was away and her mother absent, she had no means of supporting herself and over 3 weeks had only 2 gros of bread. This extreme poverty preceded her alleged seduction by the devil. She worked as a healer and charged fees ranging from 33 gros to 3.5 francs. Multiple witnesses mentioned payment for her healing services, and there are suggestions she sometimes demanded payment or complained when not paid enough. Husband was a miner.

extraction_metadata.notes: Trial shows classic pattern of healer-turned-accused. Appoline practiced healing with her mother (who was reportedly driven from her native place for witchcraft). Economic desperation central to confession narrative - extreme poverty when husband away led to alleged devil pact. Confession obtained under torture. Language region marked as 'mixed' due to German words throughout (diffel, haltzmentel, etc.) and witness testimony about German speaking, though trial conducted in French. Multiple references to payment disputes and economic tensions. Seduction date ambiguous: confession on Dec 20 says '5 years before', but under torture on Jan 3 says '10 years earlier' - both included in confession.seduction_date field. Notable that sabbat attendance confession only came under torture and was minimal (feasting, refused to go with them). Multiple harms follow quarrel-threat-harm pattern. No formal accuser mentioned - appears to be community accusations. Three justices of valley sentenced her. Burned alive Jan 4, 1581.
